previous_headings: Quick start with the example dataset
title: Get started with RCarb
text: Now want start modelling using data given first sample .  function returns terminal output along two plots, mostly similar original graphical output provided ‘MATLAB’ program ‘Carb’. example function model_DoseRate() called three additional arguments, DR_conv_factors = "Carb2007", n.MC = 10, txtProgressBar = FALSE. first argument selects dose rate conversion factors used ‘RCarb’. second argument limits number Monte Carlo runs error estimation 10 second argument prevents plotting progress bar, indicating progression calculation. arguments solely set reduce calculation time output vignette. Obviously, want run row input table separately model dose rates, run modelling samples example dataset can call model without subsetting dataset first. careful, calculation may take time. note used dose rate conversion factors: historical reasons ‘Carb’ set dose rate conversion factors, differ slightly values literature (e.g., Adamiec & Atiken, 1998) used 'RCarb' default values. However, 'RCarb' >= 0.1.3 can select dose rate conversion factors. Please type ?RCarb::Reference_Data R terminal details.
code: ##extract only the first row  data <- Example_Data[1,]  ##run model  results <- model_DoseRate(   data = data,   DR_conv_factors = "Carb2007",   n.MC = 10,    txtProgressBar = FALSE) ##  ## [model_DoseRate()] ##  ##  Sample ID:       BN107  ##  Equivalent dose:     98  ±  9 Gy ##  Diameter:        180 µm  ##  MC runs error estim.:    10   ##  ------------------------------------------------  ##  Age (conv.):         133.451  ±  16.27  ka ##  Age (new):       117.443  ±  13.21  ka ##  ##  Dose rate (conv.):   0.734  ±  0.029  Gy/ka ##  Dose rate (onset):   0.963  ±  0.071  Gy/ka ##  Dose rate (final):   0.737  ±  0.023  Gy/ka ##  ------------------------------------------------ results <- model_DoseRate(   data = Example_Data)

title: Get started with RCarb

title: Get started with RCarb
text: final modelling differ call already show (without plot output):
code: ##run model  results <- model_DoseRate(   data = data,   n.MC = 10,    txtProgressBar = FALSE,    plot = FALSE) ##  ## [model_DoseRate()] ##  ##  Sample ID:       EXAMPLE  ##  Equivalent dose:     98  ±  9 Gy ##  Diameter:        180 µm  ##  MC runs error estim.:    10   ##  ------------------------------------------------  ##  Age (conv.):         133.451  ±  12.659  ka ##  Age (new):       117.443  ±  8.743  ka ##  ##  Dose rate (conv.):   0.734  ±  0.04  Gy/ka ##  Dose rate (onset):   0.993  ±  0.086  Gy/ka ##  Dose rate (final):   0.732  ±  0.031  Gy/ka ##  ------------------------------------------------

text: R package 'RCarb' provides collection various R functions model dose rates carbonate-rich samples. package translation 'MATLAB' program Carb Roger P. Nathan.

text: install latest development builds 'RCarb' directly GitHub, run install developer build 'master', replace term 'master' code line name wanted developer build (available yet). Please note ‘GitHub’ versions developer versions subject daily changes. stable please versions download package CRAN.

Samples now organised rows parameters columns. data can used test 'RCarb' play secondary carbonatisation process. Sample HD107 renamed LV107 sake consistency Fig. 4 Mauz & Hoffmann (2014).

title: Reference data — Reference_Data
text: Reference data correction factors beta gamma radiation used internal calculations. values used instead correction factors given Aitken (1985) carbonate model.

title: Reference data — Reference_Data
text: Reference_Data: list

title: Reference data — Reference_Data
text: reference values used internally account : (1) grain size depend beta-attenuation factors (Mejdahl, 1979) (2) correct nuclide dependent beta gamma radiation water/carbonate proportions. latter values given matrix precise values interpolated modelling process. Additionally 'RCarb' provides set dose rate conversion factors convert concentrations U, Th, K dose rate values. Historically Carb (thus 'RCarb') dose rate conversion factors, differ slightly published values. provide consistent calculation approach default 'old' Carb values used, user can switch (see model_DoseRate) values provided Adamiec & Aitken (1998), Guérin et al. (2011), Liritzis et al. (2013) Cresswell et al. (2018). Different values quoted U-238 U-234 accounts different activity ratios. details origin data refer Nathan & Mauz (2008) Nathan (2010). Nuclear data origin according Nathan & Mauz (2008) gamma primary energy spectra uranium, thorium potassium drawn Evaluated Nuclear Structure Data File (ENSDF) database https://www.nndc.bnl.gov (2002-01-16) beta primary energy spectra derived ENSDF end-point energies using Fermi beta decay model (Evans, 1955) modified Behrens & Szybisz (1976). simulations collisional mass stopping powers quartz software ESTAR (Berger et al., 2000) used. mass energy-absorption coefficients quartz tabulated Hubbell & Seltzer (2004). details references please read Nathan & Mauz (2008)

title: Reference data — Reference_Data

Dose-rate conversion factors: update. Ancient TL 29, 5–9. doi:10.26034/la.atl.2011.443 Cresswell, .J., Carter, J., Sanderson, D.C.W., 2018. Dose rate conversion parameters: Assessment nuclear data. Radiation Measurements 120, 195–201. doi:10.1016/j.radmeas.2018.02.007 Liritzis, ., Stamoulis, K., Papachristodoulou, C., Ioannides, K., 2013. Re-Evaluation Radiation Dose-Rate Conversion Factors. Mediterranean Archaeology Archaeometry 12, 1–15. https://www.maajournal.com/index.php/maa/article/view/1012/921 Mejdahl, V., 1979. Thermoluminescence dating: beta-dose attenuation quartz grains. Archaeometry 21, 61-72. doi:10.1111/j.1475-4754.1979.tb00241.x Nathan, R.P., Mauz, B., 2008. dose-rate estimate carbonate-rich sediments trapped charge dating. Radiation Measurements 43, 14-25. doi:10.1016/j.radmeas.2007.12.012 Nathan, R.P., 2010. Numerical modelling environmental dose rate application trapped-charge dating. DPhil thesis, St Hugh's College, Oxford. https://ora.ox.ac.uk/objects/ora:6421 reading Aitken, M.J., 1985. Thermoluminescence dating. Academic Press. Berger, M.J., Coursey, J.S., Zucker, M.., 2000. ESTAR, PSTAR, ASTAR: Computer Programs Calculating Stopping-Power Range Tables Electrons, Protons, Helium Ions (version 1.2.2). https://physics.nist.gov/Star (2005-08-09). National Institute Standards Technology, Gaithersburg, MD. Behrens, H., Szybisz, L., 1976. Shapes beta spectra. Physics Data 6-1, Zentralstelle fuer Atomkernenergie-Dokumentation (ZAED), Germany. Evans, R.D., 1955. Atomic Nucleus. McGraw-Hill, NY. Hubbell, J.H., Seltzer, S.M., 2004. Tables X-Ray Mass Attenuation Coefficients Mass Energy-Absorption Coefficients (version 1.4). https://physics.nist.gov/xaamdi (2005-08-09). National Institute Standards Technology, Gaithersburg, MD.

what: Model dose rate evolution in carbonate-rich samples — model_DoseRate
title: Model dose rate evolution in carbonate-rich samples — model_DoseRate
text: function models dose rate evolution carbonate enrich environments. calculation internal functions called.

title: Model dose rate evolution in carbonate-rich samples — model_DoseRate
code: model_DoseRate(   data,   DR_conv_factors = NULL,   length_step = 1L,   max_time = 500L,   n.MC = 100,   method_control = list(),   txtProgressBar = TRUE,   verbose = TRUE,   plot = TRUE,   par_local = TRUE,   ... )

title: Model dose rate evolution in carbonate-rich samples — model_DoseRate
text: data data.frame (required): input data following structure given example data set data(Example_Data). input data.frame least one row (.e. values one sample). multiple rows function automatically re-called. DR_conv_factors character (optional): applied dose rate conversion factors, allowed input values "Carb2007", "Adamiec_Aitken_1998", "Guerin_et_al_2011", "Liritzis_et_al_2013". NULL triggers default, "Carb2007" length_step numeric (default): step length used calculation max_time numeric (default): maximum temporal search range n.MC numeric (default): number Monte Carlo runs used error calculation method_control (optional): additional arguments can provided control modelling. See details information. txtProgressBar logical (default): enables/disables txtProgressBar MC runs verbose logical (default): enables/disables verbose mode plot logical (default): enables/disables plot output par_local logical (default): enables/disable local par settings, set FALSE global par settings accepted. ... arguments passed underlying plot functions, see also details information. Supported standard arguments mfrow, xlim, xlab.

title: Model dose rate evolution in carbonate-rich samples — model_DoseRate
text: function returns numerical graphical output ———————————–[ NUMERICAL OUTPUT ] ———————————– data.frame combination input values calculated function. ———————————–[ GRAPHICAL OUTPUT ] ———————————– Upper plot: Dose rate evolution time backwards. solid black line calculation output, grey shaded area indicates 2-sigma error margins. dashed blue line indicator quality error estimations based Monte Carlo (MC) runs.closer follows black line, reliable given error margins. Lower plot: Totally absorbed dose time. plot representation 'new' age based carbonate modelling.

title: Model dose rate evolution in carbonate-rich samples — model_DoseRate
text: function starting point dose rate modelling carbonate enrich environments. provides basically functionality original version 'Carb', .e. also aware limitations modelling approach. particular: model assumes linear carbonate mass increase due post-depositional processes. Please read references cited blow. Uncertainty estimation estimating uncertainties, Monte-Carlo (MC) simulation runs used. small values (close 0) can, however, lead edge effects (similar 'Carb') since values 0 set 0.

title: Model dose rate evolution in carbonate-rich samples — model_DoseRate
code: ##load example data data("Example_Data", envir = environment())  ##run the function for one sample from ##the dataset model_DoseRate( data = Example_Data[14,], n.MC = 2, txtProgressBar = FALSE ) #>  #> [model_DoseRate()] #>  #>  Sample ID:		 LV107  #>  Equivalent dose:	 53  ±  2 Gy #>  Diameter:		 215 µm  #>  MC runs error estim.:	 2   #>  ------------------------------------------------  #>  Age (conv.):		 149.73  ±  9.077  ka #>  Age (new):		 130.642  ±  6.226  ka #>  #>  Dose rate (conv.):	 0.354  ±  0.012  Gy/ka #>  Dose rate (onset):	 0.518  ±  0.014  Gy/ka #>  Dose rate (final):	 0.375  ±  0.015  Gy/ka #>  ------------------------------------------------   #>    SAMP_NAME     K   K_X    T  T_X    U  U_X U238 U238_X U234_U238 U234_U238_X #> 14     LV107 0.073 0.004 0.67 0.02 0.79 0.07    0      0         0           0 #>    WCI WCI_X WCF WCF_X CC CC_X DIAM DIAM_X COSMIC COSMIC_X INTERNAL INTERNAL_X #> 14  10     2   5     5 60    2  215     35 0.0876   0.0044        0          0 #>    ONSET ONSET_X FINISH FINISH_X DE DE_X AGE_CONV AGE_CONV_X     AGE AGE_X #> 14   120      10     40       10 53    2   149.73      9.077 130.642 6.226 #>    DR_CONV DR_CONV_X DR_ONSET DR_ONSET_X DR_FINAL DR_FINAL_X n.MC #> 14   0.354     0.012    0.518      0.014    0.375      0.015    2

title: Write table input template — write_InputTemplate
text: function creates template table can used input function model_DoseRate

title: Write table input template — write_InputTemplate
text: file character (optional): output path, NULL nothing written, template data.frame returned. ... additional arguments can passed function write.table file != NULL. Supported arguments : sep, dec, fileEncoding

title: Write table input template — write_InputTemplate
text: Sebastian Kreutzer, Institute Geography, Heidelberg University (Germany)

title: Write table input template — write_InputTemplate
text: Kreutzer, S., 2025. write_InputTemplate(): Write table input template. Function version 0.1.0. : Kreutzer, S., Nathan, R.P., Mauz, B., 2025. RCarb: Dose Rate Modelling Carbonate-Rich Samples . R package version 0.1.7. https://r-lum.github.io/RCarb/

title: Write table input template — write_InputTemplate
code: ##create template without file creation write_InputTemplate() #>   SAMP_NAME    K  K_X    T  T_X   U  U_X U238 U238_X U234_U238 U234_U238_X WCI #> 1   EXAMPLE 0.08 0.01 1.64 0.08 1.9 0.08    0      0         0           0  20 #>   WCI_X WCF WCF_X CC CC_X DIAM DIAM_X COSMIC COSMIC_X INTERNAL INTERNAL_X ONSET #> 1     7   7     7 62    1  180     10   0.18     0.01        0          0   100 #>   ONSET_X FINISH FINISH_X DE DE_X #> 1      10     40       10 98    9  if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ ##Example with file output  ## set temporary filename ## (replace by own path if needed) temp_file <- tempfile(pattern = "template", fileext = ".csv") write_InputTemplate(file = temp_file)  } # }
